speaker: RESIDENT
text: Hi, I’m one of the emergency room doctors. I understand you were sent here from dialysis because of pain and drainage around your right groin dialysis catheter. Can you tell me in your own words what’s been going on with that leg and line over the last few days?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yeah, the spot where my dialysis line goes into my right thigh started hurting a little a few days ago. Then it got more swollen and tender, and this morning I saw pus around it. They did my whole dialysis run anyway and gave me some vancomycin there, then sent me here when they saw how bad it looked.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Thank you. We’re also seeing that your blood pressure is on the low side right now, around the 80s over 40s to 80s over 50s, which can happen after dialysis and with infection. We’ll give you IV fluids and start antibiotics. Have you had any fevers, chills, chest pain, or shortness of breath today?

speaker: PATIENT
text: I had chills this morning before dialysis, but no real fever that I know of. No chest pain or trouble breathing. Mostly it’s the pain in my leg and feeling kind of weak and lightheaded.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Okay. We’re going to draw blood, including cultures to look for infection in your bloodstream, and start you on IV cefepime and more vancomycin to cover line infections. We’ll also get a chest X‑ray and an EKG because of your low blood pressure. You mentioned you’re on hemodialysis for HIV‑related kidney disease and that you’re not taking HIV medications right now, but you are taking Bactrim and azithromycin for infection prophylaxis, correct?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yes, I’m on dialysis because of my HIV kidneys. I haven’t been able to stay on the HIV meds, they make me sick. But I do take the Bactrim three times a week and the azithromycin once a week like my doctor told me.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your initial labs show your kidney numbers are high as expected with dialysis, but your potassium is okay at 4.4, and your lactate is mildly elevated at 2.2, which can go along with low blood pressure and infection. Your liver tests are normal. We’re going to admit you to the ICU because of the low blood pressure and suspected infected dialysis catheter. Interventional radiology has already removed the right femoral catheter at the dialysis unit, so we’ll need to arrange new access soon.

speaker: PATIENT
text: ICU? Am I that sick? I feel a little better after the fluids, just tired. I’m worried about how I’m going to get my dialysis now that they pulled that line.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We’re bringing you to the ICU mainly to watch your blood pressure closely and manage the infection. Right now your pressure has come up into the 90s over 60s after about 3 liters of IV fluid, and you’re not needing any medications to raise it. We’ll coordinate with nephrology and interventional radiology to get a new dialysis catheter placed once the infection is under control.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. My throat has also been hurting for a few weeks, and my neck too. It gets better when I take Percocet. Could that be from thrush or something?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Given your HIV and the throat pain, we are concerned about possible oral candidiasis. We’ll have ENT examine your mouth and throat, and we’re going to start a nystatin mouthwash to treat possible thrush. We’ll also continue your pain medicines, including oxycodone and acetaminophen, and your hydroxyzine for itching.

speaker: NURSE
text: I’m going to give you your evening medications now: your cinacalcet and folic acid for your kidneys and anemia, your sevelamer with dinner to bind phosphorus, and your usual HIV prophylaxis meds on their schedule. If your throat hurts, I’ll bring the nystatin rinse as ordered.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thanks. My leg where the line was pulled is really sore. It feels swollen and warm there.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: On exam, there’s about a 10 by 10 centimeter area on your right upper thigh that’s tender, a bit warm, and fluctuant where the old catheter tunneled. We’re going to get an ultrasound of that area to make sure there’s no abscess that needs to be drained.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from the ultrasound team. We just scanned your right upper thigh where the old dialysis catheter was. There’s a lot of soft tissue swelling and a small amount of fluid under the skin, but no organized pocket of pus that we can drain. The main femoral artery and vein are open and flowing normally.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So you don’t have to cut it open? I’m glad. It still hurts a lot though.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your blood work this morning shows your white count is low at about 3.1, your hemoglobin is 11.3, and your platelets are a bit low at 108. Your kidney numbers are still high, with creatinine 6.6 and BUN 42, which is expected since you haven’t had dialysis since the line was pulled. Your troponin is mildly elevated at 0.36, but your CK and CK‑MB are normal and your EKG doesn’t show a heart attack. We think this is a stress‑related troponin rise in the setting of low blood pressure and kidney disease, not a heart attack.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’m not having any chest pain, so I’m relieved it’s not a heart attack. I do feel tired and kind of wiped out.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Your chest X‑ray from yesterday looked good—your lungs are clear and your heart size is normal, with no signs of pneumonia or fluid overload. That’s reassuring given your low blood pressure and HIV.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s good to hear. Breathing feels okay. It’s mostly the leg and just feeling down. I’ve been really depressed lately.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from psychiatry. I understand you’ve been struggling with depression and also with sticking to your HIV medications. From what you’ve told us, you’re feeling very low but you don’t have active thoughts of harming yourself. Given your side effects with amitriptyline in the past, we’re not going to start a new antidepressant in the hospital, but as an outpatient your team may consider a low‑dose mirtazapine and close social work follow‑up.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yeah, I don’t want to hurt myself, I’m just tired of being sick all the time. I’d be willing to talk to someone as an outpatient, but I’m nervous about more meds.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We’ll make sure social work and your primary HIV doctor are involved after discharge. For now, we’ll keep your prophylaxis with Bactrim and azithromycin, but we won’t restart full HAART while you’re here, in line with your outpatient plan.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from ENT. We examined your throat and larynx. There’s no mass, but there are findings consistent with oral candidiasis. Continuing the nystatin swish and swallow for a 6‑day course is appropriate, and you’ve already reported some improvement in your throat pain.

speaker: PATIENT
text: The mouthwash tastes awful, but my throat does feel a bit better than when I came in.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m the interventional radiology fellow. We tried to place a new tunneled hemodialysis catheter through your left common femoral vein today. We were able to get into the vein and start tunneling, but we couldn’t advance the catheter fully and you asked us to stop, so we removed it. There were no immediate complications, but you still don’t have a working dialysis catheter yet.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I remember, it was really uncomfortable and I got scared. I know I need dialysis though. Are you going to have to try again?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Yes, we do need to get you a new catheter so you can resume dialysis. Tomorrow, interventional radiology will try again, this time with general anesthesia so you’ll be asleep and more comfortable. Because of your history of difficult access and prior venous stenosis, it can be technically challenging, but they’ve reviewed your imaging and feel it’s feasible.

speaker: PATIENT
text: If I’m asleep for it, that’s better. I just don’t want to wake up without a line again.

speaker: NURSE
text: Your morning labs show your hemoglobin is down to about 10.3 and your platelets are around 103, and your white count is still low at 3.1. Your kidney numbers are higher again, with creatinine 8.6 and BUN 59, so nephrology is eager to get dialysis restarted once the new line is in.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I feel more tired and a little puffy. I can tell when I’m due for dialysis.

speaker: CONSULT
text: We’re the interventional radiology team again. Under general anesthesia, we successfully placed a tunneled hemodialysis catheter through your left common femoral vein with the tip in your right atrium. It was very difficult to advance the catheter past the left iliac vein and through the IVC, and a small contrast injection suggested there might be partial thrombus in the IVC. However, the catheter is functioning well and is ready for dialysis.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Because of that possible IVC thrombus seen during the catheter placement, we’re going to start you on a heparin drip while we get more definitive imaging. We’ve ordered a CT venogram of your abdomen and pelvis to see if there’s truly a clot in the IVC. If there is, we may need to continue blood thinners; if not, we’ll stop them.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Blood thinners make me nervous. I’ve heard they can cause bleeding. Do I really need that?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We understand your concern. That’s why we’re using heparin, which we can turn off quickly, and we’re checking your clotting labs regularly. If the CT shows there’s no clot, we’ll stop the heparin after about a day. If there is a clot, we’ll weigh the risks and benefits of longer‑term blood thinners, especially given your platelet counts and medication adherence.

speaker: NURSE
text: We’ve started your heparin infusion and your first dialysis session through the new left femoral catheter. Your potassium before dialysis was 5.8 and your BUN and creatinine were 70 and 10, so this should help bring those down. Let us know if you feel lightheaded or short of breath during dialysis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I feel okay so far, just the usual tired feeling. I hope this line keeps working.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from radiology. We reviewed your CT of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast. The IVC is fully opacified and there is no filling defect—so no evidence of an IVC thrombus. The catheter is in place and the IVC is patent. We also see innumerable bilateral renal cysts and two small splenic lesions that look like hemangiomas, but no retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: That’s great news: the CT confirms there’s no clot in your IVC, so we’re going to stop the heparin drip now. We’ll continue to use the left femoral catheter for dialysis. The CT also confirms the many kidney cysts we already knew about and benign‑appearing splenic lesions, so no signs of cancer there.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’m relieved there’s no clot. My leg where the new line is feels sore but not like the infected one did.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your blood counts over the last couple of days show a stable macrocytic anemia with hemoglobin around 9–10, white blood cells in the mid‑2s to low‑3s, and platelets drifting down into the 90s. Your coagulation tests are normal. We think this pancytopenia is related to your HIV and chronic kidney disease. We’ll continue to monitor, but you haven’t needed any transfusions.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’m used to my blood counts being low, they always tell me that at dialysis. As long as I don’t need a transfusion, I’m okay with it.

speaker: NURSE
text: Your labs this morning show your creatinine is down to about 4.7 and BUN 27 after dialysis, and your potassium is 4.7. Calcium is a bit low at 7.9, and your phosphorus is slightly low at 2.6, so the team has already reduced your sevelamer dose and started Nephrocaps to help with vitamins.

speaker: PATIENT
text: They told me they were cutting back the sevelamer because my phosphorus was low. I’ll take whatever pills I need if it helps me stay out of the hospital.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We also noticed your D‑dimer is quite elevated at about 6991, but given the CT showing no IVC clot and your lack of symptoms like chest pain or shortness of breath, we’re not pursuing further clot workup right now. Your lactate is normal at 1.4, and your blood cultures from admission and the next day have shown no growth, so it looks like we caught the line infection early and treated it effectively.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So even though that line looked nasty, the infection didn’t get into my blood? That’s good.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from cardiology, reviewing your rhythm issues. During dialysis you had an EKG that showed premature atrial beats in a bigeminal pattern, but your heart rate was actually around 80 and you had no symptoms. On older EKGs you’ve had atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response during sepsis. Given your low CHADS2 score and concerns about adherence, we’re not recommending warfarin. Instead, your aspirin dose has been increased from 81 mg to 325 mg daily.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I didn’t feel anything when they said my heart was acting funny. I can take the stronger aspirin if that helps and doesn’t mean more blood tests.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re looking at your most recent labs before discharge. Your hemoglobin is about 9.5, platelets have improved to 139, and white count is 2.4. Creatinine is 5.2 and BUN 34 after dialysis, potassium 5.2, and your electrolytes are otherwise stable. Coagulation tests are normal. Clinically, your blood pressure has been in the 90s to low 100s systolic without symptoms, and the right thigh infection site is healing with no fluctuance or drainage.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I feel more like myself now. The right leg is much less sore, and the new line on the left just feels like a bruise. I can walk with my cane like before.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We’re planning to discharge you home with visiting nurse services. You’ve completed a 7‑day course of vancomycin dosed with dialysis for the suspected right femoral catheter infection, and you never developed a positive blood culture or fever. Your new left femoral tunneled catheter is working well for dialysis. At home, you’ll continue cinacalcet, sevelamer at the reduced dose, Nephrocaps, folic acid, Bactrim three times a week after dialysis, azithromycin once weekly, gabapentin every 48 hours, hydroxyzine as needed for itching, oxycodone as needed for neuralgia pain, docusate for constipation, and aspirin 325 mg daily.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s a lot of pills, but I’ve been on most of them already. I’ll keep going to dialysis on my usual days. Will someone check on this new line and the old site on my right leg?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes. The visiting nurse will check your catheter sites and your right thigh wounds, and your nephrologist will see you in dialysis. We’ll also arrange follow‑up with your HIV provider to keep discussing HAART when you feel ready, and with your primary doctor for your neuralgia and anemia. If you develop fever, chills, worsening leg pain, redness or drainage around the catheter, chest pain, or trouble breathing, you should call right away or come back to the emergency department.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay, I understand. Thank you all for taking care of me. I’m ready to go home.
